summary:
Ingredients

Sauce:

1 tbsp Soy Sauce
2 tbsp Sugar
3 tbsp Gochujang
1 tsp Garlic (diced)
1 tbsp red chilli flakes or “Gochugaru”

Stock:

Anchovy broth (optional)
3 cups Water
Enoki mushrooms
Green onion
Cabbage
500g Rice Cakes
Eggs
Ramen noodles

Recipe

  1. Mix the sauce together
  2. Bring water to boil
  3. Add anchovy and simmer
  4. Mix in the sauces
  5. Throw in the veggies and rice cakes and stir till sauce thickens
  6. Add the boiled eggs and ramen
  7. Wait for a few mins till the ramen is cooked and then serve!!
  8. Optional - sprinkle seasame seeds on top!
title: Rabokki (tteokbokki + ramen)

content:
Day 1: Flight to SF Got the window seat Amazing view of the mountains! Went to the hotel, refreshed & headed out Walked around, lot of weed smell, lots of walkers! Went to Salesforce Park - amazing view and plants Went to Pier 39 Sealions, sunset, Bueno Vista cafe with Irish coffee, Lombard street in the dark, Chinese Sizzling Pot King for dinner and back to hotel & sleep! Tv was atrocious at the hotel but the view was amazing
Day 2 Onboarding! Went to chinatown in the evening but everything was mostly closed Got to see the fortune cookie place, had pineapple bun, went to Stella’s pasteries - awesome biscuits & treats, went to Golden Boy Pizza for a slice - so good! Got on the wrong direction bus hahaha, exchanged later on, went to hotel, got indian food & boba tea and slept!
Day 3 Checkout & early morning onboarding 61st floor views were so good! Boarded the expensive bus to Palace Museum and went to the beach to view the Golden Gate Bridge Got the Waymo to hotel, dropped my phone while getting down, raised the complaint, left to San Jose in Bart Met friends, planned a trip! Knocked out with indian dinner
Day 4 Pinnacle National Park - amazing park for beginner hikes! Easy hike with nice view & a cave route which was so cool to climb through. Good descent path and spotted a blue bird, some deer. Missed the concord eagles but apparently common there. Came back and collected my phone.
Day 5 Wrapped up, goodbyes! Flight back to Seatac, saw Alien Romulus Developed a headache, so slept off for rest of day.
All in all, Bay Area is soooo cool!! <3
summary:
Day 1:

Flight to SF Got the window seat Amazing view of the mountains! Went to the hotel, refreshed & headed out Walked around, lot of weed smell, lots of walkers! Went to Salesforce Park - amazing view and plants Went to Pier 39 Sealions, sunset, Bueno Vista cafe with Irish coffee, Lombard street in the dark, Chinese Sizzling Pot King for dinner and back to hotel & sleep! Tv was atrocious at the hotel but the view was amazing
title: Sfo trip

content: Adventure with cleaning blender I was trying to clean my vavsea blender and removed the o ring seal from the blender lid. Then spent a long time trying to figure out how to put it back cuz it was not too expandable and not much space! After wracking our brains (me and a friend), my friend figured out that we could remove the top part of the blender lid from the bottom covering!! Hallelujah! After this it was a piece of cake to put the seal back on and twist it into the lid. Its super funny looking back cuz being an engineer means you’re supposed to figure these things out quicker!
summary:
Adventure with cleaning blender

I was trying to clean my vavsea blender and removed the o ring seal from the blender lid. Then spent a long time trying to figure out how to put it back cuz it was not too expandable and not much space! After wracking our brains (me and a friend), my friend figured out that we could remove the top part of the blender lid from the bottom covering!! Hallelujah! After this it was a piece of cake to put the seal back on and twist it into the lid. Its super funny looking back cuz being an engineer means you’re supposed to figure these things out quicker!
title: Fun_discovery

content:
Reference: https://youtube.com/shorts/fzlokaeYOl8?si=yPBfJaqcNrlCywG2
https://youtu.be/SXDrwfUBaX8?si=W6H1UvHYXAx2kKsa
Ingredients (4 servings) Babycorn (1 trader joes pack) Cauliflower (half) 1.5 capsicum 1 onion (medium size) 1 tomato 4 green chilly 1 twig curry leaves whole spices (3 cardamom, 0.5 cinamon, 2 cloves, 1 bay leaf) kasuri methi garam masala - 1 or 2 spoons palya powder - 1 spoon coriander - 2 spoons cumin - 1 spoon salt - 2 spoons red chili - 1 spoon Recipe Prep Cut babycorn into slices diagonally Cut cauliflower Cut capsicum vertically Cut onions Cut green chilly Cook Bring oil to hot Add mustard and whole spices Add onion, green chilly and stir Add ginger garlic paste Add tomato Add spices - turmeric, cumin, coriander, kashmiri red chili, red chili, garam masala, salt Add curry leaves let it cook on medium heat for 5mins Turn off flame and let it cool In another pan add the veggies - cauliflower, capsicum, babycorn on stir fry for 5-10mins (use butter also) Grind the onion tomato mixture to fine paste Bring it to heat and let it cook Add the stir fried veggies Let it cook for 5 mins Add the heavy cream and kasuri methi for garnish and taste test.
summary:
Reference:

https://youtube.com/shorts/fzlokaeYOl8?si=yPBfJaqcNrlCywG2

https://youtu.be/SXDrwfUBaX8?si=W6H1UvHYXAx2kKsa

Ingredients (4 servings)

  1. Babycorn (1 trader joes pack)
  2. Cauliflower (half)
  3. 1.5 capsicum
  4. 1 onion (medium size)
  5. 1 tomato
  6. 4 green chilly
  7. 1 twig curry leaves
  8. whole spices (3 cardamom, 0.5 cinamon, 2 cloves, 1 bay leaf)
  9. kasuri methi
  10. garam masala - 1 or 2 spoons
  11. palya powder - 1 spoon
  12. coriander - 2 spoons
  13. cumin - 1 spoon
  14. salt - 2 spoons
  15. red chili - 1 spoon

Recipe

Prep

  1. Cut babycorn into slices diagonally
  2. Cut cauliflower
  3. Cut capsicum vertically
  4. Cut onions
  5. Cut green chilly

Cook

  1. Bring oil to hot
  2. Add mustard and whole spices
  3. Add onion, green chilly and stir
  4. Add ginger garlic paste
  5. Add tomato
  6. Add spices - turmeric, cumin, coriander, kashmiri red chili, red chili, garam masala, salt
  7. Add curry leaves
  8. let it cook on medium heat for 5mins
  9. Turn off flame and let it cool
  10. In another pan add the veggies - cauliflower, capsicum, babycorn on stir fry for 5-10mins (use butter also)
  11. Grind the onion tomato mixture to fine paste
  12. Bring it to heat and let it cook
  13. Add the stir fried veggies
  14. Let it cook for 5 mins
  15. Add the heavy cream and kasuri methi for garnish and taste test.
title: Babycorn Palya

content:
Understanding Rust Data Structures and Ownership Rust is a modern systems programming language that guarantees memory safety and concurrency without a garbage collector. At the heart of Rust’s design are ownership, borrowing, and lifetimes, which play a crucial role in how data structures are implemented and used. This blog explores Rust’s ownership model and common data structures with illustrative code examples.
Common Data Structures Vectors Vectors are dynamic arrays that grow and shrink in size. They’re owned collections, meaning their data is managed by the vector itself.
Example: Using Vectors
fn main() { let mut v = vec![1, 2, 3]; v.push(4); // Add an element println!("{:?}", v); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4] // Iterating over a vector for i in &v { println!("{}", i); } } HashMap Key Value store
Example:
use std::collections::HashMap; fn main() { let mut scores = HashMap::new(); scores.insert("Alice", 50); scores.insert("Bob", 30); // Accessing values if let Some(score) = scores.get("Alice") { println!("Alice's score: {}", score); } // Iterating over the HashMap for (key, value) in &scores { println!("{}: {}", key, value); } } The Ownership Model in Rust Rust’s ownership model has three core rules:
Each value in Rust has a variable called its owner. A value can have only one owner at a time. When the owner goes out of scope, the value is dropped. Example: Ownership and Scope fn main() { let s1 = String::from("hello"); // s1 owns the String let s2 = s1; // Ownership of the String is moved to s2 // println!("{}", s1); // Error: s1 is no longer valid println!("{}", s2); // Output: hello } Borrowing You can have multiple immutable borrows or one mutable borrow, but not both at the same time. A borrow (immutable or mutable) must always be valid for its scope. By enforcing these rules, Rust prevents data races and ensures memory safety at compile time. 1. Mutable Borrow: A mutable borrow gives you the ability to modify the borrowed value, but it enforces exclusivity. Only one mutable borrow is allowed at a time, and no immutable borrows can exist simultaneously.
Example:
fn main() { let mut v = vec![1, 2, 3]; { let v_mut = &mut v; // Mutable borrow v_mut.push(4); // Modifying the vector } // v_mut goes out of scope here println!("{:?}", v); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4] } 2. Reference (Immutable Borrow): An immutable borrow means you can read the value without taking ownership, but you cannot modify it. Multiple immutable borrows are allowed simultaneously because they don’t change the data.
Example:
fn main() { let s = String::from("hello"); let r1 = &s; // Immutable borrow let r2 = &s; // Another immutable borrow println!("{} and {}", r1, r2); // Both r1 and r2 can be used } Borrow conflict example: fn main() { let mut s = String::from("hello"); let r1 = &s; // Immutable borrow // let r2 = &mut s; // Error: Cannot have a mutable borrow while immutable borrows exist println!("{}", r1); }
summary:
Understanding Rust Data Structures and Ownership

Rust is a modern systems programming language that guarantees memory safety and concurrency without a garbage collector. At the heart of Rust’s design are ownership, borrowing, and lifetimes, which play a crucial role in how data structures are implemented and used. This blog explores Rust’s ownership model and common data structures with illustrative code examples.

Common Data Structures

Vectors

Vectors are dynamic arrays that grow and shrink in size. They’re owned collections, meaning their data is managed by the vector itself.
title: Programming in Rust

content:
Reference: Plantain Cake Making
Ingredients For serving size of 1 cake in 9x9 diameter cake
2 ripe plantains 2 cups flour 1 tsp Salt 1 Tsp baking powder 1/4 Tsp baking soda 3/4 cup sugar 8 tbsp butter or 1 stick butter 1/4 cup Yogurt 2 eggs 3 tbsp milk 1 tsp vanilla extract Recipe Preheat the oven to 350¬∞F, then grease and flour the baking pan and set aside. Combine the flour, salt, and baking powder and baking soda. Whisk, mash or blend the plantains till fairly smooth. Use a hand whisk to cream the butter and sugar for 2 to 3 minutes. Add the eggs one at a time and cream together until just combined. Add the Yogurt and vanilla and whisk together. Mix the mashed plantains with the creamed butter and add the mixture to the dry ingredients (flour, salt, and baking powder). Fold a couple of times until well mixed. (don’t over mix). Stir in the milk and mix till combined. Mix chocolate chips, some nuts such as almonds, cashews, walnuts for crunchy texture (optional) Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan. Smooth out the surface of the batter and bake for 50 minutes to 1 hr or till a tester or toothpick inserted into the middle of the cake comes out clean. Let the cake cool down and then cut it and serve!
summary:
Reference:

Plantain Cake Making

Ingredients

For serving size of 1 cake in 9x9 diameter cake

  1. 2 ripe plantains
  2. 2 cups flour
  3. 1 tsp Salt
  4. 1 Tsp baking powder
  5. 1/4 Tsp baking soda
  6. 3/4 cup sugar
  7. 8 tbsp butter or 1 stick butter
  8. 1/4 cup Yogurt
  9. 2 eggs
  10. 3 tbsp milk
  11. 1 tsp vanilla extract

Recipe

  1. Preheat the oven to 350¬∞F, then grease and flour the baking pan and set aside.
  2. Combine the flour, salt, and baking powder and baking soda.
  3. Whisk, mash or blend the plantains till fairly smooth.
  4. Use a hand whisk to cream the butter and sugar for 2 to 3 minutes. Add the eggs one at a time and cream together until just combined. Add the Yogurt and vanilla and whisk together.
  5. Mix the mashed plantains with the creamed butter and add the mixture to the dry ingredients (flour, salt, and baking powder). Fold a couple of times until well mixed. (don’t over mix).
  6. Stir in the milk and mix till combined.
  7. Mix chocolate chips, some nuts such as almonds, cashews, walnuts for crunchy texture (optional)
  8. Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan. Smooth out the surface of the batter and bake for 50 minutes to 1 hr or till a tester or toothpick inserted into the middle of the cake comes out clean.
  9. Let the cake cool down and then cut it and serve!
title: Plantaincake

content:
My investment research for USA:
Only invest if: You have no debts You have a 6-month emergency fund You’ve maxed out your 401k You’ve maxed out your IRA Brokerage accounts Fidelity Charles Schwab Vanguard Types of funds: Retirement: Can be taken out past 59.5 years 10% penalty for early withdrawal
401k (pre-tax, saves on taxable income) upto $23k per year upto a percentage of the base or a fixed $ amount (whichever comes first) will be contributed by the companies will not be considered as taxable income but will be taxed on capital gains during withdrawal Roth IRA (post-tax, saves on being taxed during withdrawal) upto $7k for 2024 can be made only from income that is taxed (i.e no other source) has to be within income i.e if income is < 2k, cant deposit more than 2k into roth has income limits (MAGI) will not be taxed on any gains during withdrawal Key Note: Both can be further invested into index funds
Health Saving Account (HSA) This can be combined with a qualifying High Deductible Plan Limit for 2025 is $4,300 (individual) Some companies contribute some money to this as well Triple tax benefits Excluded from taxable income Gains are not taxed Withdrawals are not taxed if used for health purposes We don’t have to use it right away; keep reciepts and claim it later as well Works for international claims as well Reimburse Invest into a good fund
Investment: Index Funds vs ETF’s:
Index mutual funds can only be bought and sold at the end of the trading day, based on the fund’s net asset value (NAV). ETFs trade throughout the day on a stock exchange, just like stocks, and their price fluctuates based on supply and demand. ETF’s are more tax efficient because they minimize capital gain whereas index funds are more prone to this tax (hasn’t happened in past few years tho) Types of Index funds: Comparison Tool S&P 500: Fidelity SPLG = 0.02% expense ratio VOO = S&P 500 (ETF) VFIAX = S&P 500 (Fund) FXAIX = S&P500 FZROX = (recommended for Roth) zero fees FXNAX = Diversified between US Gov’t and Corporate Bonds Total US Market: VTI = Total US Market Capture (ETF) FSKAX = Total US Market Capture (~3800 companies) VTSAX = Total US Market Capture (Fund) - more for large investment Tech Focused: QQQ and QQQM Mid Cap: VOT Small Cap: AVUV high expense ratio compared to vanguard International: VXUS Overlap between VTI and VXUS = 0 FTIHX = International (outside US) Total Market in World: VT - Vanguard Total World Stock ETF Dividend: Note: Dividends earned are taxed yearly in a taxable brokerage account 1. SCHD 2. VYM = Vanguard High Yield Dividend ETF 3.
Growth: 1. SCHG Detailed Differences Comparison Fidelity Vanguard Charles Schwab Expense Ratio (S&P 500) 0.015% (FXAIX) 0.04% (VFIAX), 0.03% (VOO) 0.02% (SWPPX) Things to Consider before selecting the fund Who runs the fund and how long have they been at the helm. What other funds do they run? What is the fund’s investment strategy? What are the specific risks of this strategy besides the general risks of investing. How has the fund been performing compared to some industry benchmark and other funds with a similar investing strategy. Percentage of diversification (recommended is 70% us market, 20% international, 10% bonds) Expense Ratio How will you be taxed on taxable brokerage withdrawals? On withdrawal of money within 1 year, short term gains tax is applied (which is high) After 1 year, withdrawals are subject to capital gains tax (15% category) Sale of shares is done by default from Fidelity via FIFO i.e earlier shares are sold first to minimize short term gains Terms to Know: Margin Interest Rates:
we can borrow money against the principle being the stock that we own in the brokerage. this is how the brokerages make money. Expense Ratio:
percentage of the investment in the fund that is paid for owning the fund. References: Fidelity vs Vanguard vs Charles Schwab
Index Mutual Funds vs ETFs
Portfolio Management
Average Annual Returns Comparison
Taxation for Gains
HSA limits
summary:
My investment research for USA:

Only invest if:

  • You have no debts
  • You have a 6-month emergency fund
  • You’ve maxed out your 401k
  • You’ve maxed out your IRA

Brokerage accounts

  1. Fidelity
  2. Charles Schwab
  3. Vanguard

Types of funds:

Retirement:

Can be taken out past 59.5 years
10% penalty for early withdrawal

  1. 401k (pre-tax, saves on taxable income)
    • upto $23k per year
    • upto a percentage of the base or a fixed $ amount (whichever comes first) will be contributed by the companies
    • will not be considered as taxable income
    • but will be taxed on capital gains during withdrawal
  2. Roth IRA (post-tax, saves on being taxed during withdrawal)
    • upto $7k for 2024
    • can be made only from income that is taxed (i.e no other source)
    • has to be within income i.e if income is < 2k, cant deposit more than 2k into roth
    • has income limits (MAGI)
    • will not be taxed on any gains during withdrawal

Key Note: Both can be further invested into index funds
title: IntroToInvesting

Step 1: hugo new –kind page posts/Post_Name.md Step 2: update the content Step 2.5: update base url with hugo -b url Step 3: hugo server Step 4: hugo –minify (prod build)
Step 4: navigate to public/ folder and git push
Video Tutorial https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LIFvgrRxdt4&t=1s
summary:
Step 1: hugo new –kind page posts/Post_Name.md
Step 2: update the content
Step 2.5: update base url with hugo -b url
Step 3: hugo server
Step 4: hugo –minify (prod build)
Step 4: navigate to public/ folder and git push

content:
Sonarcloud: Useful to get static code analysis.
Configuration with Azure Pipelines:
# Prepare SonarQube analysis configuration. - task: SonarQubePrepare@3 inputs: SonarQube: # string. scannerMode: 'MSBuild' cliProjectKey: # string. Required when scannerMode = CLI && configMode = manual. Project Key. projectKey: # string. Guidelines:
Ensure to use version 3 and above. Previous ones are deprecated and will not be able to find the generated test analysis files. If the code and tests are under the same src folder, then write the files that need to be excluded in the .xml file: <ItemGroup> <TestProjects Include="src/Tests/**/*.csproj" /> </ItemGroup>
summary:
Sonarcloud: Useful to get static code analysis.

Configuration with Azure Pipelines:

# Prepare SonarQube analysis configuration.
- task: SonarQubePrepare@3
  inputs:
    SonarQube: # string. 
    scannerMode: 'MSBuild'
    cliProjectKey: # string. Required when scannerMode = CLI && configMode = manual. Project Key. 
    projectKey: # string.

Guidelines:

  1. Ensure to use version 3 and above. Previous ones are deprecated and will not be able to find the generated test analysis files.
  2. If the code and tests are under the same src folder, then write the files that need to be excluded in the .xml file:
<ItemGroup>
    <TestProjects Include="src/Tests/**/*.csproj" />
</ItemGroup>
title: Sonarcloudlearning
